News this is All Things Considered I'm Robert Siegel and I'm Mary Louise Kelly
President Trump is expected to make
a major announcement next week that could unravel the nuclear deal with Iran he
faces
a congressional deadline to certify that Iran is abiding by the deal and also to
certify that the deal is c.n.n.
America's national security interests all indications are that he's going to say it
is not N.P.R.'s Michele Kelemen reports back when the Iran deal was negotiated by
the Obama administration most lawmakers opposed it so Congress passed
a law requiring the president to certify every 90 days that the deal is working the
agreement limits Iran's nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief President
Trump clearly doesn't like this certification requirement and he's left little
doubt about what he thinks of the deal itself that deal is an embarrassment to the
United States if Trump as expected refuses to certify this time Congress will have
60 days to decide whether to snap back sanctions and if that happens the u.s.
Will be breaking the deal known as the way the Trump administration could work to
ensure that Congress doesn't act or change the law that requires the president to
weigh in Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has also been suggesting ways to push
back at Iran's other nefarious activities in the region we're going to give him
a couple of options of how to move forward. The important policy towards Iran as
you've heard us say many times that. Represents only
a small part of the many issues that we need deal with when it comes to Iran
relationship Democratic lawmakers say they're ready to counter Iran's bad behavior
but argue it's risky to raise doubts about
a deal that is working and is keeping Iran's nuclear program in check the ranking
Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee Ben Cardin is frustrated that
the Trump administration is trying to hand this off to Congress for the trouble
ministration to imply. It is just sending this to Congress is just flat
wrong this is an executive judgment we urge the president to
stay with the agreement if there are no violations we want to see the agreement in
force Carden was
a critic of the Iran deal but now that it's in place he says at least it's ensuring
there are limits to Iran's nuclear program and us sanctions relief is part of the
deal it's
a mixed message to say he's not certifying but still allowing the sanction relief
to go forward it's
a mixed message Republican Senator Tom Cotton told the Council on Foreign Relations
this week that the strategy is to decertify and then fix the deal and he argues
that the 60 day period during which Congress could snap back sanctions should give
the u.s.
Some leverage now I'm not sure that 60 days is long enough to conduct the kind of
course 'd of diplomacy I've mentioned if it's obvious by the end of that 6 day
period that the course of action I recommended will not work and perhaps we will
have to repair sanctions down but I'm also willing to give the administration and
our allies in Europe and the Middle East more time than just 60 days to try to get
a better deal some of his biggest complaints include the fact that key restrictions
on Iran's nuclear program start phasing out after 10 years cotton is also pushing
for tougher inspections and threatening u.s.
Military action if necessary Iran has made clear it's not open to renegotiating the
. Yes And so to have the other is Russia China the u.k.
France and Germany who point out that it was endorsed by the u.n.
Security Council 2 years ago Senator Chris Murphy
a Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee put it this way when he spoke at the
Center for American Progress Europeans simply will see the claim that Trump and his
nonexistent state department will be able to magically negotiate
a better deal as laughable fantasy he says the most legitimate criticism of the
nuclear deal with Iran is that it doesn't last forever but Murphy argues the u.s.
Is in a stronger diplomatic position to start laying the groundwork for
a follow on agreement only if the u.s.
Continues to abide by it Michele Kelemen n.p.r.
News the State Department Senator Dan Sullivan sits on the Armed Services Committee
he's an Alaska Republican Sullivan was an assistant secretary of state during the
George w.
Bush administration during which time he worked on sanctions and he's been
a critic of the Iran nuclear deal Senator welcome to the program good to be here
Robert thanks to you this year you said that President Trump should let the Iran
deal fail on its own you know now going further than that saying it should be
declared
a failure and sanctions should be imposed straightaway Well actually I didn't say
he should let it fail on its own I said he should vigorously enforce it not still
my position I think that you know almost before the ink was dry and Iran was
clearly violating the spirit and I think the latter of many aliments of the
agreement so to keep us leadership I think we shouldn't walk away from it we should
niggers lean Forsett try to get. A ranch you correct the violations and if
not then take action including the possibility of snapback sanctions like Secretary
Kerry and President Obama talked about but the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of
Staff General Joe Dunford told your committee this week that Iran in his words now
is not in material breach of the agreement and he said that he thinks keeping the
agreement is in America's national security interest. That's what's your reply to
General Dunford Well look as you can imagine
a lot of respect for General Dunford and General Mattis I'm not sure exactly what
he means by material breach but I believe that Iran is clearly defying the spirit
and letter in intent of the nuclear deal and again I think the president should
take the leadership position of pointing that out to all the parties including Iran
where they're violating it and say you have the opportunity to cure the violations
and if you don't then we're going to take actions pursuant to the agreement which
would include snap back sanctions just to pursue what might be being in material
breach and not being in material breach you have written about some Iranian actions
you say are violations of the deal but has Iran moved any closer to having
a nuclear weapon since this deal take effect Well look I think the entire I don't
know the answer to that to be perfectly honest but I think when you look at the the
broader issue there is
a clear violation for example of the amount of having water that they were allowed
under the agreement there is
a connection with regard to the ballistic missile testing that they've been
undertaking in violation of u.n.
Security Council resolution 2231 so the agreement can't just be looked at just
solely from the objective of have they moved forward more closely with regard to
nuclear weapons it needs to be looked at in terms of the overall spirit in what
they committed to do in Robert on
a number of things what they committed to do they've already violated but Secretary
of State former Secretary of State Kerry has written about negotiating this deal
and 1st he said you know what we really can deal with what really was urgent here
was the nuclear program we have lots of other disagreements we had many other
problems with Iran but this was the one that there was broad consensus among our
allies our other members of the Security Council to address and so yeah it doesn't
cover and every other issue that. It deals with the nuclear program isn't that what
it's all about moment again and it's not just the violations that I've had problems
with with regard to the agreement it's the overall structure of the agreement
remember even if Iran is completely abiding by all elements of this nuclear deal
and by the end of the decade even if they've complied with the agreement almost
allows them to legally be on the threshold of being part of the community of
nations that have nuclear weapons I think having another road terrorist regime on
the verge of having nuclear weapons is not in the interest of the United States was
one of the big flaws of the deal and right now they're showing that they're not in
compliance with Senator Sullivan thank you very much for talking with us today
thank you Robert Senator Dan Sullivan Republican of Alaska.
The trumpet ministration is rolling back an Obama era health care mandate it had
required employers to pay for birth control through their insurance plans and the
trumpet ministration is leaving that mandate in place but under its new rule nearly
any employer can opt out of paying for birth control if they have
a religious or moral objection that has already led to lawsuits N.P.R.'s Allison
Kojak has more the Affordable Care Act included birth control among the services
that company health plans are required to cover but religious groups objected and

figured out
a way for women to still get their birth control. Covered without the companies

a lot more companies could end up having to pay full price for contraceptives
rather Severino leads the Office of Civil Rights at the Department of Health and

should have
a space for organizations to live out their religious identity and not be
discrimination depending on who you talk to today's change may amount to

any religious or moral reasons would be allowed to refuse birth control for their

News this is All Things Considered I'm Mary Louise Kelly and I'm Robert Siegel the
deadly mass shooting in Las Vegas happened on Sunday and now on Friday
investigators are revealing little if any of the clues they're pursuing into the
mystery of why the shooter did this n.p.r.
Correspondent Leila Fadel joins us now from Las Vegas and lay the what's the latest
in the investigation Well law enforcement had their 1st briefing for the media in
over and day and there is still no answer to that big question why local and law
enforcement in partnership with the f.b.i.
Have run down over
a 1000 leads they're sorting fact from fiction and Clark County Undersheriff Kevin
McMurray has said repeatedly today really with
a hint of exasperate that they don't know why the shooter did this I will tell you
though that all of the rumor and speculation has not been helpful to our
investigation in the past terror attacks or mass murder incidents motive was made
very clear very clear in most of those cases by a note that was left by
a social media post by
a telephone call that was made by investigators mining computer data today in our
investigation we don't have any of that uncovered. I wish we did now the f.b.i.
Is asking for the public's help they're calling for anyone who knows anything to
call them and they're putting it up on billboards across Las Vegas if you know
something say something with their tip line they're confident that the shooter was
alone in that room but they they want to know if if he spoke to anyone if anyone
knows anything about what led up to all of this and they're looking at everything
from birth to death now yesterday the authorities released
a complete list of the deceased How is the city coping with the aftermath of all
this well this is a city that's grieving there was
a vigil last night to honor Charleston Hartfield who was an off duty Los Vegas
police officer at the concert
a veteran he was killed along with $57.00 other people and thousands of people
turned out to honor him the city's opening a memorial garden tonight with
a wall of remembrance and $58.00 trees one for each victim and they're also
celebrating their heroes make Mayhill today mentioned tases Campos who's the
security guard who went to that room on the 32nd floor when the are alarm was
triggered and got shot and notified police so that is how Las Vegas right now is
trying to deal with the aftermath Well you know live in Las Vegas and you know that
the reconned Israel and the town gates go in the gamblers arrive in the like what
are the signs whether this will or won't be the case this weekend so sure after
this tragedy Yeah I mean all week we've been seeing more and more people coming to
Las Vegas I've been seeing the throngs of people crossing the streets hard to make
a turn and it's Friday that's the day people are checking in and there are people
checking in last night I was at the Bellagio and I saw brides just walking through
the lobby for also seeing
a little bit of heightened security as well security guards at parking lots
checking people's cars if they're bigger cars we're seeing more people posted in
parts of the casino to look so you're definitely seeing heightened security but it
doesn't seem to be stopping people from coming here so N.P.R.'s Leila Fadel in Los
Vegas leather Thanks thank you so much. The. New York Times has published
a blockbuster story detailing allegations of sexual harassment against someone
considered
a king and queen maker in Hollywood thank you Harvey Weinstein Harvey and Bob
Weinstein and Harvey bested Harvey Weinstein movie mogul Harvey Weinstein who was
behind big hits like Pulp Fiction life is beautiful and Chicago so how is Hollywood
reacting to these accusations smile with
a shrug Weinstein's behavior was apparently notorious amongst his staff actors
executives publicists Ken Masters is the host of the business on Casey or w.
And she's editor at large of The Hollywood Reporter I asked her to describe the
power Weinstein holds in Hollywood in the day Harvey Weinstein was
a magician in the Oscar race many people have had statuettes on their mantle
because of him but in recent years last few years it's been
a lot rougher and I actually don't think it's
a total coincidence that this report about him is coming out at
a time when he is kind of low up in his terms of his career in
a dry spell well before we get to that describe the behavior in question What
exactly are these allegations Well I mean we have been hearing allegations about
Harvey Weinstein for years some of which but not all are in the New York Times
article that just ran he has
a pattern allegedly of asking women to meet him in hotels ostensibly for business
purposes and if they agree and go to these meetings he has
reportedly been in various stages of undress including Total one dress pressuring
them for massages and all sorts of pressure to engage in activities that clearly
have nothing to do with business to
a greater or lesser degree of aggressiveness you said this is something that you
have been hearing about for years I mean then the number of lawsuits that the New
York Times is reporting he has settled would come to at least 8 over the years some
and has this been just an open. Secret in Hollywood it has been actually an open
secret more or less and you know many people in our line of work you know some
people are saying why why wasn't the story broken sooner believe me many of us have
tried to literally over the course of the last couple of decades what might be the
consequences going forward for him I mean does is it possible can you see
a scenario that where he sits out a season or 2 and then comes back with
a hit at all is forgiven No I don't see that actually I think he's his name is very
toxic right now he is fighting for his professional life obviously apparently very
passionately pleading to be allowed to guaranteed that he can return if he takes
a leave if he if that He will to address these demons of his but I just don't see
this being a thing I mean there comes
a point where you're beyond the point of no return the last thing I ask you is just
the backdrop for all of the times have changed this is not the 1st sexual
harassment case to make headlines in the media and entertainment world I mean we've
all followed the Bill Cosby. Trial and then of on the news media side there's Fox
News and Roger Ailes and Bill O'Reilly I mean how does this fit into that wider
context Well clearly times have changed and women are speaking out more and that's
a good thing I mean this behavior has gone on for years that the places you
mentioned and you know we're in 2017 and I feel hope that this is
a wake up call to people that this behavior is simply unacceptable and not to be
tolerated and the days of the producer on the casting couch asking for asking for
services outside the realm of acting maybe finally getting put to rest I mean that
is
a trope you know the producer on the casting couch and I'm sure it was very true in
the past and somewhat true today but the kind of course of behavior that's being
alleged here that is
a standout even within the Hollywood community like you might hear about somebody.
You know making
a positive woman or pressuring her saying I will give you in this role if you do
that for me but but I will say that in the in the chatter in Hollywood for
a long time now Harvey has been an outlier in terms of the pattern of behavior
that's alleged thanks very much Ken thank you that's Ken Masters he is host of the
business on case here w.
And also editor at large of The Hollywood Reporter.
And the Weinstein Company board of directors released
a statement this evening strongly endorsing Harvey Weinstein's decision to take an
indefinite leave of absence from the company beginning today as for what comes next
that's still an open question the Weinstein company has hired
a law firm to do an investigation and report to the.

News and I'm Devin Katayama in October 2014 Cecilia Lam 8 calls to San Francisco

a more holistic way the story was written by San Francisco Chronicle reporter Vivian

a lawsuit and it was in that point in time that I learned more about what really

happening all over the country. There are cases even now this year where
the message violence victims are calling the police for help only to die later
Cecilia Lam called police several times police actually responded they showed up to
her home where she was living with roommates What were some of those interactions
like the police showed up 3 times in the issue with with each of those interactions
is that none of the officers according to depositions considered
a domestic violence call even though she is very clear in her no one calls to

a Young Jr was acting out that he was drunk that he needed to leave and he wasn't

of the night. She believed that Cedric Young had tried to poison her. She was
making fake id and the sauce had some very substance in it she believed this
happened her roommate brought it down and asked the officer to look into it but the
officers never did it turned out after that sauce was tested
a year after her death that it was actually poisoned that there was rat poison
inside it 2 days before lamb was killed San Francisco updated its policy for
responding to domestic violence did that change anything at all the policy was very
thorough the policy was very well thought out it really takes into consideration
all the complexities of domestic violence it warns officers not to be thrown off
by lack of injury says not to be thrown off by
a victim's reluctance to cooperate the issue with this case is not so much the
policy but more making sure officers recognized the message violence as domestic
violence in your story you write about police responding proactively and also
reactively can you tell us about the domestic violence it's not always
a punch in the face it's not always
a visible injury police officers they really can't wait for it to get to that level
before taking action. It's one of the message violence of Fortunately is
a very complicated
a very difficult kind of crime to suss their own and with the situations of police
officers really have to treat it as the worst case scenario they have to treat the

a possible death event thank you so much thank you Vivian Ho reports for The San
